Lex_Rijger:
{{Short description|Surinamese country music singer (1944–2021)}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2021}}

'''Alexander Lodewijk Antonius Rijger''' (2 December 1944 – 23 June 2021)<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|last=Iwan Muradin|date=3 July 2021|title=De uitvaart van Alexander Lodewijk Antonius Rijger m.b.a. Lex Rijger.|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TXyFY7DZPnM|website=(video)|language=nl}}</ref> was a [[Suriname|Surinamese]] [[Country music|country]] singer and songwriter.  He was known for his television specials for Christmas and Mother's Day.  Before becoming a musician, he was a basketball player and referee, founding the local club SCVU.

He wrote one of the [[SuriPop]] 2008 finalist songs, "A Song of Life", which was performed by his three daughters.  His youngest daughter [[Zoureena Rijger]] was [[Miss Suriname]] 2009.

== Career ==
Rijger attended the Paulus School in Suriname.<ref name=":2" />  He played for the local [[basketball]] teams CLD and De Arend.  As a leader of the Social Cultural Association Uitvlugt (SCVU in Dutch), Rijger decided to start a basketball team for the area.<ref name=":5" />  After studying basketball training<!--in Dutch source: "masterstudie"--> in [[Mexico]], he returned and founded the team SCVU with Paul "Pa Lefi" Leeflang<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|last=Wajwakana|first=Audry|date=2 July 2021|title=Lex Rijger was een coole guy|url=http://www.dwtonline.com/laatste-nieuws/2021/07/02/lex-rijger-was-een-coole-guy/|access-date=5 July 2021|website=De Ware Tijd|language=nl}}</ref> in 1964, becoming its vice-president.  He also worked as a [[Official (basketball)|referee]].  Although Rijger later shifted his focus to music, he maintained ties with SCVU.<ref name=":2" />  Under Rijger's leadership, the SCVU team was promoted to the top league of the Suriname Basketball Federation.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|date=5 July 2021|title=Waardering sportpioniers|url=http://www.dwtonline.com/laatste-nieuws/2021/07/05/commentaar-waardering-sportpioniers/|access-date=17 July 2021|website=De Ware Tijd|language=nl}}</ref>  In 1969, Rijger took a job with the tax authorities as a [[Bailiff#Netherlands|bailiff]], which he would maintain for 35 years.<ref name=":4" />

Rijger began his career in music in the 1970s: he started a band called 'The Drifter', which played [[Pop music|pop]], [[blues]] and [[oldies]].  In the 1980s, his sister Magda Jessurun-Rijger asked him to enter a [[country music]] festival with her.  They then decided to start a band called "Country Roads", which would host [[line dance]] nights.  When Magda emigrated to the [[Netherlands]] in the 1990s, Rijger continued solo, sometimes collaborating with other country artists like René Nelson.  Rijger performed at casinos, hotels (like the Hotel [[Torarica]]), and house parties throughout Suriname; he would also organise and perform in [[Television special|television specials]] for [[Christmas]] and [[Mother's Day]].  Rijger wrote many of his own songs, including Christmas songs.<ref name=":4" />  He also started the Country and Western Music Suriname foundation.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Khoesiaal|first=P.|date=23 June 2021|title=Countryzanger Lex Rijger overleden|url=https://www.dbsuriname.com/2021/06/23/countryzanger-lex-rijger-overleden/|access-date=5 July 2021|website=Dagblad Suriname|language=nl}}</ref>

== Family ==
Rijger married Nisa Chandoe<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Neijhorst|first=Julian|date=20 February 2019|title=Zussen Rijger: ‘Eens zal pa niet meer weten wie we zijn’ – Parbode Sneak Peek|url=https://www.parbode.com/zussen-rijger-eens-zal-pa-niet-meer-weten-wie-we-zijn-parbode-sneak-peek/|access-date=5 July 2021|website=Parbode|language=nl}}</ref> in 1984.  Rijger and Nisa had five children: two sons and three daughters.  One son died in infancy.  The remaining four children (son Garry and daughters Cheryll, Xaviera and [[Zoureena Rijger|Zoureena]]) joined Rijger in his performances when they were older: Garry would be the [[Disc jockey|DJ]], and the sisters would sing as a trio.  As Rijger also played football in recreational clubs, he did occasional coaching of the youth [[Association football|football]] teams Puwa Nani and Bintang Baru '82, and would have his children attend the practices.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|date=16 June 2009|title=De familie Rijger|url=https://www.parbode.com/de-familie-rijger-2/|access-date=5 July 2021|website=Parbode|language=nl}}</ref>

Garry died in 2004: while walking along a road, he was hit by a [[taxi]] whose driver had [[Sleep-deprived driving|fallen asleep at the wheel]].  Rijger was greatly impacted by Garry's death: he took early retirement from his job as a bailiff, and stopped performing for three years.  He returned slowly to performing, with Nisa as the DJ.<ref name=":2" />  For four months in 2007, the family ran their own club, the "Lex Rijger Countryclub" on [[Henck Arron]] Street in [[Paramaribo]]; after the club closed, they continued holding line dancing events at different venues.  Rijger's original song "A Song of Life", performed by his daughters, was one of the ten final selections for [[SuriPop]] in 2008.<ref name=":4" />  His youngest daughter [[Zoureena Rijger]] was [[Miss Suriname]] 2009.<ref>{{cite web|date=24 November 2009|title=Geen prijs voor Rijger bij Miss World Talent|url=http://www.dbsuriname.com/archief/nat/2009/nov09/24-11-09/Nat_Geen%20prijs%20voor%20Rijger%20bij%20Miss%20World%20Talent%20.asp|work=Dagblad Suriname|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928095103/http://www.dbsuriname.com/archief/nat/2009/nov09/24-11-09/Nat_Geen%20prijs%20voor%20Rijger%20bij%20Miss%20World%20Talent%20.asp|archivedate=28 September 2011|url-status=dead|language=nl}}</ref>

His eldest daughter Cheryll married the actor Ruben Welles in 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|date=14 April 2019|title=Surinaamse zangeres Cheryll Rijger trouwt met komiek Ruben Welles|url=https://www.waterkant.net/suriname/2019/04/14/surinaamse-zangeres-cheryll-rijger-trouwt-met-komiek-ruben-welles/|access-date=5 July 2021|website=Waterkant|language=nl}}</ref>  His daughters continued to perform one or two country songs in their concerts even while they shifted to more [[house music]] and [[Pop music|pop]].<ref name=":1" />

== Illness and death ==
Rijger's last performance was in 2013.  He was diagnosed with [[Alzheimer's disease]] in 2014, but had been experiencing forgetfulness and other symptoms for several years before.<ref name=":4" />

He died on 23 June 2021 at the age of 76.<ref name=":4" />   His funeral was held on 2 July<ref name=":3" /> at the [[Saint Peter and Paul Cathedral, Paramaribo]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Alexander Lodewijk Antonius Rijger|url=http://www.dwtonline.com/familienieuws/2021/06/29/alexander-lodewijk-antonius-rijger/|access-date=17 July 2021|website=De Ware Tijd|language=nl}}</ref>  The newspaper ''[[Dagblad Suriname]]'' called him "a piece of [[Texas]] in Suriname".<ref name=":0" />
